value: caption=The Soyuz launch pad, Gagarin's Start is seen prior to the rollout of the Soyuz TMA-13 spacecraft at the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan, Friday, October 10, 2008

Baikonyr is famous worldwide for its

, the site of many spacefaring feats including the first operational ICBM, the launch of Sputnik and the launch of the first manned orbital flight by Yuri Gagarin.  The modern town of Baikonyr was built near the existing village of
(Төретам), the name still used by the railway station, and was known as
(Ле́нинск) until renamed in 1995 by then-president of Russia, Boris Yeltsin.
The easiest way to visit Baikonyr, and the only way to visit the cosmodrome, is by guided tour. Prices vary wildly but are always steep: a one-day tour starting from
starts from US$700 per person, while a multi-day excursion from
can cost US$5,000. as the cosmodrome area (6000 km
.) is rented by Russia, no Kazakh visa is needed if you fly in directly from Moscow.
Baikonyr's two airports, Krainiy (in city) and Yubileyniy (in cosmodrome) serve only semi-regular chartered flights from
.  The nearest town with scheduled service is
(267 km away), which has scheduled daily flights to Almaty and
Baikonyr's station, Toretam, is on the Moscow-Almaty main line.  The station is 1445 km from Almaty and the trip takes around 27 hours on an express train.

value: .  A large quantity of Russian's exploration of

was launched from here.  Permits are necessary and must be arranged at least 45 days in advance; the only practical way of doing this is through a specialist travel agency.  Visits during space launches are particularly popular, but scheduling is subject to unpredictable delays.
